content.description:
Ken protected this one with hooks and called it "R", most folk will chose to TR it!  

  Climb the face a few feet left of Bean's & Franks arete.   

  My notes say: " Rope pulled off one rock, and I had two handholds break off and there's a 3rd 'ready to go' [5/2/1999] "

climbs.name: Tomahawk
climbs.fa: Sam Slater, Chad Hussey, Ken Nichols, June 1982

content.description: On the far right side of the wall, you can set a TR to the right of 3rd crack.  Climb up intricate faces to the finish.

Find the right-most crack which drops into a large overhang.  The overhang is fun to pull if you want to start it that way. Follow the crack to the ledge above.  There is a good crack at the top to set a belay, or you can hike up to the pine trees and set one from there.  The crux section is pulling through the bulge in the center of the climb, but it is well protected.  The rest of the route is pretty sustained, but there are some rests.  Most people consider this route 5.7+.

Usually this one is top-roped from the 2nd Crack TR. Pull the difficult overhang to the right of 2nd Crack and continue up thin face moves to the top. Pulling the bottom crux moves was one of the highlights of my CT climbing days, even if it was on TR. Sustained 5.9+ moves get you to the top.[substituted "right" for "left" and fixed typo, "moves" for "moved"]
content.protection: Top Rope. Use a long static to build an anchor off of trees high above near the hiking path, and extend the masterpoint down to the narrow ledge below. Center the masterpoint between the two small trees on the narrow ledge.

content.description: Comprised of two very short pitches.  The first is a 4th class scramble up a gully to a large ledge.  The second is an obvious finger crack up a more vertical face. The crack takes a ton of pro, but the feet aren't great so beginning leaders should take care.
content.location: This climb is located just to the right of Cracked Wall. Scramble over the top and walk off right through the "party zone". Hop over the short wall to the descent trail.

content.description: Climb middle right leaning crack on the wall.    This is my favourite climb on the cracked wall.  Interesting crux sections with a crack that just fades away.  The crux has no protection and puts you in ground fall, so don't head up this one unless you know you can climb it.  There are two pines at the top ledge that can be used for a TR, or you can head all the way up and use some beefier trees.
content.protection: Crux has no protection with ground fall potential, so watch out.  Otherwise, Gear to 1", nuts and cams.  I think I usually bring a ball-nut or two on this one for the thin crack near the top.

content.description:
Another "protected"-with-hooks-climb!  Most will chose to TR it.  

  START: About half way between Third Crack and Tomahawk. Climb up the face (I remember a bulge/small OH about 2/3rd of the way up??) and finish on a short hand crack.

climbs.name: Quasar
climbs.fa: Mike Heintz, Chad Hussey, Ken Nichols, June 1981

content.description: Far left on Cracked Wall, between the corner and First Crack.
content.protection: Not much pro.  Trees at top suitable for TR anchors.

climbs.name: Montana Wildhack
climbs.fa: FA: Kim Smith, Eric Butterfield, April 1976

content.description: Climb the face between First and Second Crack
Climb's the first obvious crack in the wall on the far left of Cracked Wall. A beginner's trad lead with great protection on near-vertical rock. Large holds and rests to place protection.
content.protection: Trad gear- no fixed anchor - sucks up gear- some perfect nut placements.
content.location: Climb the obvious first crack using many jugs and have a blast! Walk down to the right end of the crag.

climbs.name: Beans and Franks
climbs.fa: Bob Clark, Don Pelletier, Gary Martin, July 1980

content.description: Climb the arete on the far right of Cracked Wall
content.protection: Takes very little pro.  Best toproped.  Suitable trees at top for anchors.
content.location: The arete on the far right of Cracked Wall.  Scramble over the top and walk off right through the "party zone". Hop over the short wall to the descent trail.

content.description: The wall to the right of entertainer, with three distinct cracks.
